rev.diff:
Line 187: Line 187:
*On 19 June 2011, Bitcoin prices against the USD remained high, despite a security breach of the Mt. Gox Bitcoin Exchange, which notably caused the leaking of usernames, emails and [[MD5 hash]]ed passwords of over 60,000 users onto the Web. A majority of those passwords were also [[Salt (cryptography)|salted]]. Passwords that were not salted had not been used recently. The price of a Bitcoin briefly dropped to $0.01 on the Mt. Gox exchange (but remained unaffected on other exchanges) after a hacker using credentials from a Mt. Gox auditor's compromised computer illegally transferred a large number of Bitcoins to himself and sold them all, creating a massive "ask" order at any price. Within minutes the price rebounded to over $15 before Mt. Gox shut down their exchange and canceled all trades that happened during the hacking period.<ref>[http://forum.bitcoin.org/index.php?topic=24727.0 MtGox Clarification on June 19 hack]</ref> The exchange rate of Bitcoins quickly returned to near pre-crash values.<ref name="mick">Jason Mick, 19 June 2011, [http://www.dailytech.com/Inside+the+MegaHack+of+Bitcoin+the+Full+Story/article21942.htm Inside the Mega-Hack of Bitcoin: the Full Story], DailyTech</ref><ref>Timothy B. Lee, 19 June 2011, [http://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/news/2011/06/bitcoin-price-plummets-on-compromised-exchange.ars Bitcoin prices plummet on hacked exchange], Ars Technica</ref><ref>Mark Karpeles, 20 June 2011, [https://support.mtgox.com/entries/20208066-huge-bitcoin-sell-off-due-to-a-compromised-account-rollback Huge Bitcoin sell off due to a compromised account â rollback], Mt.Gox Support</ref><ref name="register1">{{cite news | title=Bitcoin collapses on malicious trade â Mt Gox scrambling to raise the Titanic | url = http://www.theregister.co.uk/2011/06/19/bitcoin_values_collapse_again/ | date = 2011-06-19 | author=Chirgwin, Richard |
*On 19 June 2011, Bitcoin prices against the USD remained high, despite a security breach of the Mt. Gox Bitcoin Exchange, which notably caused the leaking of usernames, emails and [[MD5 hash]]ed passwords of over 60,000 users onto the Web. A majority of those passwords were also [[Salt (cryptography)|salted]]. Passwords that were not salted had not been used recently. The price of a Bitcoin briefly dropped to $0.01 on the Mt. Gox exchange (but remained unaffected on other exchanges) after a hacker using credentials from a Mt. Gox auditor's compromised computer illegally transferred a large number of Bitcoins to himself and sold them all, creating a massive "ask" order at any price. Within minutes the price rebounded to over $15 before Mt. Gox shut down their exchange and canceled all trades that happened during the hacking period.<ref>[http://forum.bitcoin.org/index.php?topic=24727.0 MtGox Clarification on June 19 hack]</ref> The exchange rate of Bitcoins quickly returned to near pre-crash values.<ref name="mick">Jason Mick, 19 June 2011, [http://www.dailytech.com/Inside+the+MegaHack+of+Bitcoin+the+Full+Story/article21942.htm Inside the Mega-Hack of Bitcoin: the Full Story], DailyTech</ref><ref>Timothy B. Lee, 19 June 2011, [http://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/news/2011/06/bitcoin-price-plummets-on-compromised-exchange.ars Bitcoin prices plummet on hacked exchange], Ars Technica</ref><ref>Mark Karpeles, 20 June 2011, [https://support.mtgox.com/entries/20208066-huge-bitcoin-sell-off-due-to-a-compromised-account-rollback Huge Bitcoin sell off due to a compromised account â rollback], Mt.Gox Support</ref><ref name="register1">{{cite news | title=Bitcoin collapses on malicious trade â Mt Gox scrambling to raise the Titanic | url = http://www.theregister.co.uk/2011/06/19/bitcoin_values_collapse_again/ | date = 2011-06-19 | author=Chirgwin, Richard |
publisher = The Register }}</ref> This incident sparked a new breed of Bitcoin trading websites claiming better security.<ref>Forum Announcement, June 28, 2011, [http://forum.bitcoin.org/index.php?topic=23938.0 Security Audit Results for Camp BX], Camp BX Security Audit - Public Review</ref><ref>VentureBeat, July 07 2011, [http://venturebeat.com/2011/07/07/camp-bx-bitcoin/ VentureBeat - Making Bitcoin Trading Legit], VentureBeat - Making Bitcoin Trading Legit</ref>
publisher = The Register }}</ref> This incident sparked a new breed of Bitcoin trading websites claiming better security.<ref>Forum Announcement, June 28, 2011, [http://forum.bitcoin.org/index.php?topic=23938.0 Security Audit Results for Camp BX], Camp BX Security Audit - Public Review</ref><ref>VentureBeat, July 07 2011, [http://venturebeat.com/2011/07/07/camp-bx-bitcoin/ VentureBeat - Making Bitcoin Trading Legit], VentureBeat - Making Bitcoin Trading Legit</ref>
â
* September 6, 2011, Microsoft pressed the [[Reserve Bank of Australia]] to support bitcoin and other virtual currencies.<ref>http://www.finextra.com/news/Fullstory.aspx?newsitemid=22921</ref>{{Not in citation given|date=September 2011}}
+
* September 6, 2011, Microsoft pressed the [[Reserve Bank of Australia]] to support bitcoin and other virtual currencies.<ref>http://www.finextra.com/news/fullstory.aspx?newsitemid=22921</ref>
* September 9, 2011, people from [[Something Awful]]'s forum hacked into the Bitcointalk forums, stole the password hash, and injected code to alter the site into a Cosbycoin (successor [[cryptocurrency]]) forum complete with gags. <ref>http://www.scmagazine.com.au/News/271688,bitcoin-forum-hacked-by-donor.aspx</ref> <ref>http://cryptome.org/0005/bitcoin-hashleak.htm</ref> <ref>http://buttcoin.org/bitcointalk-forums-hacked-bill-cosby-pimping-new-cosbycoins%E2%84%A2-to-all-the-members-breaking This one constantly updates with links to new news articles</ref> <ref>http://alphavilleherald.com/2011/09/cosbycoin-forum-hack-pops-bitcoin-forum-bubble.html</ref> <ref>http://bitcoinnews.net/2011/09/10/bitcointalk-forums-hacked-bill-cosby-pimping-new-cosbycoins%e2%84%a2-to-all-the-members/</ref> <ref>http://www.meneame.net/story/bitcointalk-foro-official-unofficial-bitcoin-hackeado-eng</ref>
* September 9, 2011, people from [[Something Awful]]'s forum hacked into the Bitcointalk forums, stole the password hash, and injected code to alter the site into a Cosbycoin (successor [[cryptocurrency]]) forum complete with gags. <ref>http://www.scmagazine.com.au/News/271688,bitcoin-forum-hacked-by-donor.aspx</ref> <ref>http://cryptome.org/0005/bitcoin-hashleak.htm</ref> <ref>http://buttcoin.org/bitcointalk-forums-hacked-bill-cosby-pimping-new-cosbycoins%E2%84%A2-to-all-the-members-breaking This one constantly updates with links to new news articles</ref> <ref>http://alphavilleherald.com/2011/09/cosbycoin-forum-hack-pops-bitcoin-forum-bubble.html</ref> <ref>http://bitcoinnews.net/2011/09/10/bitcointalk-forums-hacked-bill-cosby-pimping-new-cosbycoins%e2%84%a2-to-all-the-members/</ref> <ref>http://www.meneame.net/story/bitcointalk-foro-official-unofficial-bitcoin-hackeado-eng</ref>
<ref>http://fancyshowtech.tv/2011/09/episode-7-cosbycoins-bitcoin-review/</ref> <ref>http://siliconangle.com/blog/2011/09/12/forum-user-passwords-possibly-stolen-in-bitcointalk-org-bill-cosby-hack/</ref>
<ref>http://fancyshowtech.tv/2011/09/episode-7-cosbycoins-bitcoin-review/</ref> <ref>http://siliconangle.com/blog/2011/09/12/forum-user-passwords-possibly-stolen-in-bitcointalk-org-bill-cosby-hack/</ref>
